text: This video is brought to you by Ting.
Get $25 of phone credit in the link down bellow

This is a mini-arcade machine, and I love
it.

I love it in a way different from the way
I have loved say my Nintendo Switch.

And it might have to do with something called,
the Ikea Effect.
But I am getting a bit ahead of myself.
Let's start from the beginning.
This is Picade kit from PIMORONI.

You do not buy a full arcade out of this box,
you buy the parts to create your own Arcade

and if you add as Raspberry Pi, charger and
OS, you can have the table arcade you
have always dreamed of.

An even though it is a bit on the pricy side
I impulse bought one when I visited the Raspberry

Pi store on the last video but, why would
I want to do that versus, say, buying a premade
Arcade machine?
That... takes me back to the Ikea effect.

If you live in a certain part of the world
you might be familiar with Ikea.

Stores that sell usually very good furniture
for comparatively low prices because they
take out the cost of labour.

When you buy Ikea furniture you get all the
parts for it and then you have to put it together
at home.
Here is the part that is interesting.

People tend to like their furniture better
if they put it together and a series of studies

by Michael I. Norton of Harvard Business School,
Daniel Mochon of Yale, and Dan Ariely of Duke

identified that we are psychologically predisposed
to like more the things we have in part built
and put effort into.
And they named this…
The Ikea Effect.

There is a beauty in creation and the Ikea
effect might explain why people who put together

their own PCs, for example, tend to grow more
attached to their creations no matter how
crappy they are.

This might also be why Nintendo started to
experiment with the cardboard programmable
labo kits.

The Maker movement all stems from the joy
of creativity and raspberry pi is right in
the middle of it.

These miniature barebones ARM computers have
traditionally offered a lot of power for a

low price with deep hardware access that allows
them to be the brain in a very large number
of projects.
Many of them being gaming projects.

So, let's imagine you want to join in the
fun and start building projects or you want

to help someone else join the fun and build
electronics skills but you have zero maker

experience, you have no idea how to do electronics
or acrylics or materials but you still want
to get started.
That is where this sort of kits comes in.

Everything that you need is here, part, electronics,
wires, instructions... well, almost everything.

You will also need The Raspberry Pi itself,
and micro SD card for the OS and 2.5 Amp or

more micro USB charger which is why
I picked all that stuff from the store at

the end of the video and while the box says
you only need a Phillips screwdriver in practice

you will also need a regular slotted tip as
well.

Also, if you have giant man hands like my
own you will likely need some sort of nipper
for the small nuts.

I imagine there is a fair number of video
tutorials for the assembly of some versions

of this kit, but for the sake of the experience,
I decided to try and use only the included
instructions.
This was a journey for sure.
The 2 narrow parts go on the top and base of the screen and hold it in place.
Place them with the flat edges... flat edges
aligned flush with the top and base of the screen assembly and the cutouts towards the middle
of the screen assembly
What... the ****... is that supposed to mean

I consider myself a… pretty good English
speaker but some of these explanations were

a bit harder to visualize than I expected
and took some fiddling and several ”aha”
moments before it all made sense.

Once you sort of get the logic of how this
thing was planned it slowly makes sense but

the first 30 minutes are by far the hardest
in terms of understanding what you are supposed
to do.

Another observation is that the kit came with
this sheet of corrections and clarifications

to the instructions and I am not sure when
you are supposed to read this.

Read them first and you have no idea what
they are talking about.

Read the after the instructions and you risk
making mistakes and then having to disassemble

to fix them, as I did on the screen because
I applied the wrong screws.
So I guess you will have to try and read both simultaneously.

You start by assembling one side of the cabinet,
then the screen which you should do very carefully

and cleanly unless you like hair or dust stuck
inside the screen once you finish the build.

And after wrongly screwing the Raspberry Pi 3
B+ that is going to power this whole thing

and having to struggle to take it all apart,
wiring the buttons to the Pi was surprisingly
easy thanks to
this little guy called a Picade X hat.

One of the cool things about the Raspberry
Pi ecosystem is the sheer amount of cool electronic

accessories for it, on this case, this hat
goes on top of the Pi connected the GPIO pins

and facilitates many of the inputs to the
buttons, along with a digital to analogue
converter for the speaker.
Pretty nice!

And then putting the console with all the
buttons together and wiring everything carefully.

If you are going to engage with projects on
a serious level you eventually are going to

have to learn how to solder but since that
can be a bit intimidating if you are new or

if you were always terrible soldering during
your 6 years of Engineering school and the

thing still makes you a bit nervous, I appreciated
the care that was put into selecting components

and cables that could be all put together
without any extra tools or soldering.

Do keep track of what number each button is
on the cables or it could get messy.

What I do not appreciate is that of the last
nuts and bolts of this assembly require some

positioning in tight corners where you can
not see what you are doing that required either

taking off some of the buttons or just a ton
of patience.

So, after an utter lack of proper cabling
that would drive any serious PC Builder in
insane, I was ready to give this a try.

"I will be surprised if this works on the
first try"

So after turning it on a number of things
were not working.

First thing was no image to the screen which
ended up being caused by two things.

One was that the ribbon cable of the screen
was apparently not plugged in correctly to

the LCD controller, which was a pretty easy
fix,

and the other was simply that Raspberries
sometimes have a bit of a hard time detecting

monitors that are powered by their USB ports,
something that can be fixed with a single

line on the boot/config.txt configuration
file.

The trickier one was that any operating system
was not just recognizing the button and stick
inputs.

I tried figuring this one for a bit when I
noticed something about the Picade X Hat.

I had connected it to the GPIO pins but had
noted that it did not seem to be fully physically

supported on all sides which were odd, and
when I pressed my finger on its side the LED

on it would light up which suggests it was
wrongly connected.

Turns out the hat needs to be connected all
the way down.

Something I missed because this requires a
bit more force than I was comfortable with.

Like, enough force to bend the plastic of
the console in a way that made me nervous.

Maybe I should have ignored the instructions
and mounted that first before mounting the
whole Pi to the console.

But hey, after the config scripts are downloaded
or running this is finally working.

Let's try some games, and start with the elephant
of the room.

The main purpose of many of these devices
is... the emulation of classic systems and
their games.

Emulation is a tricky topic on this channel because
while the development of emulation is on itself

not illegal in most countries I am familiar
with the distribution of ROMs is on a grey
area

And the discussion on the topic can be complicated
as certain companies will use the copyright

on platforms like YouTube to take down discussion
the topic that might be considered dangerous
to their brand.

This is also why I have been avoiding certain
video topics on games that I personally really
like and a lot of people are interested in.

Personally, I believe emulations of older
systems is an extremely important part not

only of game preservation but on keeping the
classic of gaming alive,

as well as creating tools that have allowed
to examine older games in new and exciting
ways.

For the purposes of this video, emulation
is an interesting tool to talk about the Raspberry

Pi and the community that has built around
it.
But why emulation?
Why not pc games like CSGO?

Quick and very simplified explanation about
CPU architecture.

PCs like the ones you play games on run on
what is called x86-64 architecture.

PC Games are made for this architecture and
a specific operating system like Windows.

While there is a lot of progress on tools
like Steam Play that allow Windows game to

work on Linux distributions this needs it
to be on the same architecture which is why

Steam Play will not allow you to play games
on a Raspberry Pi as many people emailing
me seem to believe.

Raspberry Pis use the ARM architecture, the
same one used by Phones, Ipad, tablets and

the such and this is why you will not really
see people playing Fortnite on this thing.

But emulation of older Arcade games or consoles
is possible due to a large number of open

source emulators that have been recompiled
for ARM and Retropie is a collection of script
to get those emulators compiled easily.

And Playing those games with physical arcade
controls is just really cool.

With these results, one has to wonder why
isn't it more common to see attempts at developing
or porting games natively for Pi.

When I bought this kit I had the opportunity
to chat with Eben Upton, one of the original

creators and founders of Raspberry Pi and
when I asked if he was surprised about all

the gaming people were doing on Pis he had
some interesting things to say:

No, I think I've actually been surprised in
the other direction.

I've been surprised that there aren't more,
there isn't more gaming in Raspberry Pi, This
is a big Retro Gaming community.

There's obviously a lot of retro gaming, that's
not surprising.

I have to say, I'm surprised that there isn't
more- there isn't a significant native gaming

world on Raspberry Pis, so you have a small
number of open source games that have been,

you know, Quake 3, sort of been ported to
it.

So you know, there are some games that have
been, there are some games that have been
ported.

There are- There's the Retro Emulation World,
um, but I'm kind of surprised.

We've sold 26 million Raspberry Pi's, not
all of those into consumers, lots of those

are going to our industry but there are millions
of Raspberry Pi's on people's desktops and

on people's televisions and is kind of on
some level a bit surprising to me that there
isn't a game industry.
Maybe there's a...

I mean, there's always a copyright protection
issue, you know we're a very open platform

and therefore it would be hard to enforce
a copy protection strategy on the system but...
yeah, I don't know, I'm surprised.

I think all other computer systems that have
come to be at the scale of Raspberry Pi, have
had a games' industry.

I'd still love to see that, that's a thing
I talk about a lot internally is “how do

we attract the attention- how do we make a
case to games companies that there's an economic

reason, an incentive- why they should be interested
in our platform”.

I have had the same question regarding native
game development on what is a very popular
platform.
Is it a lack of tools or incentives?

I don’t know and I would be curious to hear
your thoughts on comments.

From the community standpoint very few precious full
game engines are open source, which is needed

to port them to the platform, and even with
that porting an engine is no small feat and

progress for many interesting games can happen
quite slowly.

Believe me, I have been trying to do a video
on native raspberry pi gaming for a while

and even though the community is making a
brave effort the state of things can be a
bit rough.

There are, however, interesting native
gaming experience on Pi you have not heard
about.
Let's talk about Pico 8.

Pico-8 is a Virtual Machine created by Lexaloffle
Games that run on a variety of devices, including

directly on Raspberry Pi so... it kinda counts
as a native game?
The line is blurred.

In any case, Pico-8 is an environment that
has all the tools required to create graphics,

logic and sound to create simple games under
very specific limitations, and it also has

the tools to package and distribute this games
and everyone with access to the console can

also mod, change and repackage any games as
a derivative creation.

This openness combined with design limitations
bread creativity and the results are absolutely
delightful.

I was originally aware of Pico-8 because of
Celeste.
You might have heard of the Indie game hit.
I am a big fan of this game

and you might have seen me losing my mind
when it won some categories on the game awards.

This lovely piece of art is the successor
to a Pico-8 project of the same name,
so naturally, I wanted to try the original.

What I did not know is how many other interesting
indie titles are in there.

I have absolutely used way more time than
I expected to explore this thing and since

pico-8 has been ported to the browser you
can easily try out some of these games yourself
if you are interested.

I have fallen so much in love with this concept
that I am figuring out how to make a video
about that topic that appeals to a general audience, but this is not that video so back to the arcade.

Playing them with actual arcade controls is
super fun.

If you want the full coding environment on
raspberry pi, with all the games available

through an internet connection, it is not
very expensive

Here are some other quick examples to show
you the amazing variety of cool stuff that
has been developed here.
Shadows of Dunich.

A tactical grid combat game which pushes the
boundaries of what you can do with the limited
buttons.

Great if you are a fan of stuff like Xcom
or Advance Wars.
Orul.

What initially looks as a simple platform
becomes a bit more interesting when you realize

that that there are invisible objects that
show only on reflections and real objects

that have no reflection, forcing you to thing
to solve each level.
Some really creative stuff.

And Fuz... a demake of the classic indie hit
Fez.
Look at this thing.
Look at how neat it looks!

I expected to mostly do emulators but now
between that and Pico-8 this machine is going

to have a performant place on my current living
room and will have a place on my future LowSpecGamer

office or studio... when I can afford one
which might happen when I stop impulsively
buying cool stuff.
So in conclusion.

While the Picade kit is a bit on the costly
side and has some questionable assembly decisions
did I love the final results.
Very
Very much.

Maybe it is the Ikea effect but if you want
to find an entry point into Pi projects with

a low barrier of entry this... this is pretty
good and I deeply enjoyed having made this

video so I can justify its purchase a tax-deductible
business expense.
8/10, would impulse buy again.

If building a kit like this helps build up
your courage to attempt something a tad more

complex you might want to consider adding
mobile internet capabilities.

While modern Pis include wifi and Bluetooth
out of the box there are hats out there that

allow the use of mobile internet for more
outdoor projects.

This will of course require a sim card, which
can be a bit irritating… unless you use
something like Ting.

Ting is a mobile operator were you only pay
what you use at good rates, which means that

if you spend a lot of time on wifi or need
a sim card for an occasional PI project all

you need is to grab a SIM card from their
online shop and you are good to go because
there are no contracts or prepaid plans.

It has coverage on the United States with
compatibility with pretty much any phone and

if you use the link down in the description
you get $25 of credit for your phone bill

The average Ting bill is just $23 a month
per phone, so that's essentially a month of
free service, why not give it a try?

Make sure to show them some love, as their
help is invaluable in keeping this channel
going and as always thank you for watching.
